results.title: Storm of fire: World War II and the destruction of Dresden
results.brief_description: Presents a compelling documentary of the historical events that led to and included the destruction of Dresden, Germany, in February 1945. The events of the war between Germany and the Allies are followed from the early days of German victories to the eve of the bombing. The film shows the total devastation of Germany’s morale and strength. It is comprised of the actual sights and sounds of the events taken from archive footage and recordings. The culminating destruction is one of history’s terrible commentaries of the consequences and tragedy of total war.

results.title: Storm in a teacup
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Stuart McDonald
results.brief_description: Cecil is retired and enjoying the twilight of his life. Freida is a widow who enjoys spending time at the local swimming pool, especially after she meets Cecil. Cecil and Freida soon become intimate companions (much to the amusement of some of Cecil’s mates from the croquet club), and Cecil becomes determined to fulfil his life-long dream of sailing to New Zealand - but is it too late? This film captures the essence of a generation who have plenty of time to enjoy themselves and is a positive look at senior citizens which illustrates that “old age” is really only as old as you feel!

results.title: Storm boy. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation, Learning Corporation of America, Matt Carroll and Henri Safran
results.brief_description: Edited version of the feature film of the same name produced in 1977. Story of a boy who lives with his widowed father in a comfortable but ramshackle beach house amidst coastal sand dunes in South Australia’s Coorong. He befriends three young pelicans orphaned by hunters who have shot the mother bird. Adapted from the book of the same title by Colin Thiele. Cast includes Peter Cummins, Greg Rowe, David Gulpilil.

results.title: Storm and stress
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: A line of satellite dishes stretches to the horizon as storm clouds loom overhead. A tornado funnels across a plains landscape at high speed. Through remarkable imagery of majestic natural phenomena, Storm and Stress evokes the beauty, terror and power of the tension between the forces of nature and technology. Hall’s sequences are based on natural elements — air, fire, water — and the industrial counterparts that echo them — wind tunnels, Tesla coils, hydroelectric plants. Hall’s allusions to Sturm und Drang, the 19th-century Romantic aesthetic of the apocalyptic sublime, and the notion of the Pathetic Fallacy, in which natural upheaval reflects the individual’s inner turmoil, are expressed through powerful visual metaphors.

results.title: Storm = Lei Yu
results.creator_credit: Shanghai Film Studio and Sun Daolin
results.brief_description:
This film adaptation of the famous novel of the same name is a popular modern retelling of many traditional Chinese tropes, such as self-deception, corruption of the soul, incest and murder, all wrapped in the semblance of contemporary issues. While the plot is highly complex, it turns out that they are all related to one another and by tragic circumstance, almost all of them wind up either killing themselves out of grief or being struck by a thunderbolt.

During the days China’s Nationalist government, a powerful aristocrat is pushing his workers to the brink, shooting rioters and hiding away in his enormous Western-styled manor with his two sons and young wife.

The house is introduced to us by the servants as full of ghosts, implying the lingering memory of unresolved wrong-doings. The young, but sickly, lady of the house seems have become displeased with the pretty little maid, who has won the affections of not only her son and elder stepson, but also her husband.

The two boys express their desire to elope with the maid, and the mother reveals that she has had an affair with her step son Ping and is in love with him. Meanwhile it becomes clear to the maid that she is the daughter of the master of the house, making her and the son brother and sister. The fact that they have committed incest drives them mad.

It is also revealed to the master of the house that this happened as a result of him casting his wife out while she was pregnant for his current younger wife, and that they had not two, but three children. After ruthlessly quashing the striking workers, he finds that their leader is none other than his own son.

Despite any shortcomings expressed in the narration, this was a highly engaging drama in the way it was shot.

Cultural History of the Film:

The book from which this film was adapted is an inheritor of a long tradition of family dramas in Chinese literary history. The most famous precedent for this highly popular genre was the semi-autobiograpical Qing Dynasty epic novel “Dream of the Red Chamber” (红楼梦, a.k.a. “Story of the Stone”) by Cao Xueqin. The “Red Chamber” has reached such epic status in Chinese literature that there has long been a school of study devoted specifically to this work, known in English as “Redology”.
(4 stars - James Donald; 8 June, 2011)

results.title: Stork
results.creator_credit: Tim Burstall and Associates, Bilcock and Copping Film Productions and Tim Burstall
results.brief_description:
Adapted for the screen by David Williamson from his own stage play, Tim Burstall’s broad, low-budget comedy is one of the earliest, and most commercially successful, releases of the 1970s Australian film ‘renaissance’.

The adventures of the seven-foot-tall, Marcuse-quoting, would-be-revolutionary ‘ocker’, Stork, (Bruce Spence) satirise many aspects of contemporary Australian society and values. “The targets of its humour are the social goals and values of the middle-classes - conformity, ambition, marriage, the pretensions of the corporate world or the academic and art establishments.” (Tim Burstall).

results.title: Stories from a flying trunk
results.creator_credit: EMI/Parlophone, John Brabourne, Richard Goodwin and Christine Edzard
results.brief_description: Entertaining children’s film combining the use of live action, animation and ballet to present adaptations of three Hans Christian Andersen fairytales - The Kitchen, The Little match girl and Little Ida - where nanimate kitchen objects come alive, vegetables stage a ballet and magic fills the air. Featuring members of the Royal Ballet, including Lesley Collier (Princess Ida), Graham Fletcher and Denise Nunn with choreography by Frederick Ashton, music by Rossini arranged by John Dalby and conducted by Philip Gammon. Cast also includes Murray Melvin, Ann Firbank, John Tordoff, John Dalby, Patricia Napier, Tasneem Maqsood (the match girl), Johanna Sonnex (Ida).

results.title: Stories and songs of the people: they came for gathering (A)
results.creator_credit: f-reel, ABC-TV (Australia). Indigenous Program Unit, Indigenous Unit, AFC, Johnnie Aseron and Fiona Cochrane
results.brief_description: This video documents the first ‘Stories and songs of the people’ event held in Australia at the Forum theatre, Melbourne in 1999. This event was organised by “grass roots” community and gave the opportunity for many Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal artists to express a collective future through music. It’s aim was to create a cultural and educational exchange with other Indigenous groups from around the globe. bearing in mind similarities which exist between some Indigenous peoples, eg the Native American and the Australian Aborigine’s colonisation and dispossession, their traditional links to the land and the loss of their identity. Music is seen as a healing process towards reconciliation. Performing artists include Frankie Yamma, Peter Rotumah, Deb Morrow, Kelli Howell, Neil Murray & Stephen Teakle, Shane Howard, Illana Atkinson, Tom E. Lewis, Tiffany Eckardt & Dave Steel, Nick larkins, Lee Morgan, Russell Smith, Malcolm Jagamuarra and visiting Native American artist Johnnie Aseron. Video support notes included.

results.title: Stories and songs of the people: the second stage
results.creator_credit: Film Victoria, F-Reel Pty Ltd, Fiona Cochrane and Johnnie Aseron
results.brief_description: Participants in the Stories and Songs of the People weekend tell their personal stories and provide a perspective on living in a world dominated by white culture. The struggles of indigenous peoples in Australia and some other parts of the world are explored through these individual experiences. A selection of music and songs performed during the weekend provide a backdrop to the discussion.
